quoteFirst: On his way home with an empty cart and a docile pair of oxen, progress was necessarily slow. A man who rises at three or
quoteLast: in the morning in order to put in a fair day’s work before nine o’clock in the evening, has an excuse for becoming drowsy at times of inaction. Ben had sampled the rum, found it good and tried it again, after which, knowing that his oxen would probably find their way through the coming strip of woodland without any guidance from himself, he stretched out upon the cart and was soon fast asleep.
title: New England Joke Lore: The Tonic of Yankee Humor
author: Crandall, Arthur G. (Arthur George), 1858-1935

quoteLast: , and left Barton at about six; rained all the way almost. A beautiful village at the foot of a hill with trees. A gentleman's house converted into a lady's boarding-school....
title: Journals of Dorothy Wordsworth, Vol. 1 (of 2)
author: Wordsworth, Dorothy, 1771-1855; Knight, William Angus, 1836-1916 [Editor]

quoteLast: De Failly also drew off; he had then just received a duplicate of the order directing him upon Beaumont. He sadly deplores the mischance, and pathetically relates how all his wearied troops reached Beaumont “during the night,” except the rear-guard, which did not enter the camp until five o’clock on the morning of the 30th.
title: The Campaign of Sedan: The Downfall of the Second Empire, August-September 1870
author: Hooper, George, 1824-1890

title: Journal of an Expedition into the Interior of Tropical Australia, in Search of a Route from Sydney to the Gulf of Carpentaria (1848)
author: Mitchell, T. L. (Thomas Livingstone), 1792-1855

quoteFirst: It was awkward work, and they decided that they would take aboard merely enough for a two days’ run and fill again where things were more convenient. So they put in thirty gallons and called it off. It was then
quoteLast: , and they decided to go ashore awhile before taking the launch out to her anchorage. After they had reached the village street Nelson stopped.
title: Four Afloat: Being the Adventures of the Big Four on the Water
author: Barbour, Ralph Henry, 1870-1944

quoteFirst: "April 19.--Fresh carriers arrived, and we started at 10.45 A.M., and halted
quoteLast: --twelve miles. Forest and high grass as usual throughout the route, which would render this country highly dangerous in case of hostilities.
title: Ismailia

quoteFirst: Dayton, and Mrs. Holridge (she lived up the long steps), and Mrs. Waldow, and the rest of them, to let Caroline and Grace and Fanny and Susan, and the rest of _them_, come
quoteLast: , to spend the afternoon and take tea, if it was convenient."

quoteFirst: Remove my night-gloves, and assist me to rise: it is past

quoteLast: next morning, the wind, which had been mostly at north-east, shifted to north. This being against us, I gave up the design of going within the island, or into the bay, as neither could be done without loss of time.
title: The Three Voyages of Captain Cook Round the World. Vol. VI. Being the Second of the Third Voyage
